key_insight: Parametric terrain-following vertical coordinates can be made learnable and optimized end-to-end by backpropagating through a weather model's dynamical core using automatic differentiation, removing the need for hand-tuned decay scales.
problem_solved: Reduces grid-imprinted spurious horizontal and vertical motions caused by distorted coordinate layers over steep topography, replacing heuristic, fixed-scale coordinate formulations (e.g., hybrid/SLEVE) with data-optimized coordinates.
method: Define a differentiable, parametric family of vertical coordinate transforms with a small set of learnable parameters or functions.

Run the atmospheric dynamical core forward and compute a physics-aware loss (e.g., measures of spurious motion, forecast error, stability), then use automatic differentiation through the core to obtain gradients w.r.t. coordinate parameters.
Optimize parameters end-to-end (with constraints/regularization to preserve monotonicity and numerical stability) and evaluate against standard coordinate formulations.
impact: Shows how differentiable physics can be used to learn numerical discretizations and model coordinate choices, enabling automated, data-driven tuning of modeling components that were previously hand-crafted—reducing manual effort and improving forecast fidelity over complex terrain.
visual_elements: Before/after schematic: terrain cross-section with standard terrain-following grid (distorted layers) vs learned coordinate layers (smoothed, less slanted).
Pipeline flowchart: parametric coordinate → dynamical core (forward) → loss computation → automatic differentiation → parameter update.
Bar/line chart: quantitative comparison of spurious motion metrics or forecast error for baseline (Hybrid/SLEVE) vs learned coordinates across representative topography cases.
Icon set: mountain + distorted grid, gear/graph representing optimization, and AD/gradient symbol to emphasize differentiable physics.
paper_title: Learning vertical coordinates via automatic differentiation of a dynamical core
paper_authors: Tim Whittaker, Seth Taylor, Elsa Cardoso-Bihlo, Alejandro Di Luca, Alex Bihlo
